messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Modified DDPG car-following model with a real-world human driving experience with CARLA simulator

Paper Abstract: Abstract In the autonomous driving field, fusion of human knowledge into Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) is often based on the human demonstration recorded in a simulated environment. This limits the generalization and the feasibility of application in real-world traffic. We propose a two-stage DRL method to train a car-following agent, that modifies the policy by leveraging the real-world human driving experience and achieves performance superior to the pure DRL agent. Training a DRL agent is done within CARLA framework with Robot Operating System (ROS). For evaluation, we designed different driving scenarios to compare the proposed two-stage DRL car-following agent with other agents. After extracting the ”good” behavior from the human driver, the agent becomes more efficient and reasonable, which makes this autonomous agent more suitable to Human-Robot Interaction (HRI) traffic.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Drones chasing drones: Reinforcement learning and deep search area proposal",
        "End to end learning for self-driving cars",
        "End-to-end driving via conditional imitation learning",
        "Exploring the limitations of behavior cloning for autonomous driving",
        "Offline reinforcement learning with pseudometric learning",
        "CARLA: An open urban driving simulator",
        "Opendrive 2010 and beyond–status and future of the de facto standard for the description of road networks",
        "Performance of lidar object detection deep learning architectures based on artificially generated point cloud data from carla simulator",
        "Off-policy deep reinforcement learning without exploration",
        "Nonlinear follow-the-leader models of traffic flow",
        "Train here, drive there: Simulating real-world use cases with fully-autonomous driving architecture in carla simulator",
        "Deep reinforcement learning for robotic manipulation with asynchronous off-policy updates",
        "Causal confusion in imitation learning",
        "How to start training: The effect of initialization and architecture",
        "Formulation and validation of a car-following model based on deep reinforcement learning",
        "Near-miss determination through use of a scale of danger",
        "Integrated networking, caching, and computing for connected vehicles: A deep reinforcement learning approach",
        "Robot operating system: A modular software framework for automated driving",
        "Deep q-learning from demonstrations",
        "Efficient deep reinforcement learning with imitative expert priors for autonomous driving",
        "Navigating occluded intersections with autonomous vehicles using deep reinforcement learning",
        "A new approach to linear filtering and prediction problems",
        "Calibrating car-following models by using trajectory data: Methodological study",
        "Car-following model based on fuzzy inference system",
        "Normalization methods for input and output vectors in backpropagation neural networks",
        "Offline reinforcement learning: Tutorial, review, and perspectives on open problems",
        "Continuous control with deep reinforcement learning",
        "Self-improving reactive agents based on reinforcement learning, planning and teaching",
        "Autonomous vehicle implementation predictions",
        "Improved deep reinforcement learning with expert demonstrations for urban autonomous driving",
        "Extended time-to-collision measures for road traffic safety assessment",
        "Playing atari with deep reinforcement learning",
        "Human-level control through deep reinforcement learning",
        "Making ngsim data usable for studies on traffic flow theory: Multistep method for vehicle trajectory reconstruction",
        "A multiple-goal reinforcement learning method for complex vehicle overtaking maneuvers",
        "Deep learning based object detection model for autonomous driving research using carla simulator",
        "Towards practical hierarchical reinforcement learning for multi-lane autonomous driving",
        "On the theory of the brownian motion",
        "Nonstationary kalman filter for estimation of accurate and consistent car-following data",
        "Ros: an open-source robot operating system",
        "Real-time dynamic object detection for autonomous driving using prior 3d-maps",
        "End-to-end deep reinforcement learning for lane keeping assist",
        "Mastering the game of go with deep neural networks and tree search",
        "Mastering chess and shogi by self-play with a general reinforcement learning algorithm",
        "Estimating acceleration and lane-changing dynamics from next generation simulation trajectory data",
        "Stanley: The robot that won the darpa grand challenge",
        "Robust u-net-based road lane markings detection for autonomous driving",
        "Congested traffic states in empirical observations and microscopic simulations",
        "Traffic flow dynamics",
        "The intelligent driver model with stochasticity-new insights into traffic flow oscillations",
        "Leveraging demonstrations for deep reinforcement learning on robotics problems with sparse rewards",
        "A reinforcement learning based approach for automated lane change maneuvers",
        "Simulation des Straßenverkehrsflusses"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Modified DDPG car-following model with a real-world human driving experience with CARLA simulator, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
